results.headline: Carnage and Chaos, Heavy on the Gore
results.summary_short: Arnold Schwarzenegger leads a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs in “Sabotage,” and the bodies and bullets fly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sabotage

results.headline: Brass Band of Brothers, a Dad’s Gift
results.summary_short: In Reuben Atlas’s documentary about the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, the band’s musicians grapple with the ideals of the Chicago trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brothers Hypnotic

results.headline: If Only Orson Welles Had Starred
results.summary_short: “Jodorowsky’s Dune” is a documentary about the Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky’s efforts in the 1970s to turn the science fiction novel “Dune” into a feature film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jodorowsky's Dune

results.headline: Strangers, but Their Eyes Meet on a Train to Paris
results.summary_short: In “Just a Sigh,” a middle-aged actress traveling from Calais follows an intriguing stranger to a funeral and starts an affair.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just a Sigh

results.headline: Pursuing Sex With a Bad Boy
results.summary_short: “It Felt Like Love” considers the dangers of teenage desire through the experiences of a coltish 14-year-old girl who randomly fixes on a weed-smoking tough guy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Felt Like Love

results.headline: Alone Then, Supported Today
results.summary_short: Freida Mock’s documentary about Anita Hill, who accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during his Supreme Court confirmation hearings, segues from 1991 to the present.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anita

results.headline: An Empty Suit, but Such Fine Material
results.summary_short: In “The French Minister,” Thierry Lhermitte embodies classy chaos in the title role of Bertrand Tavernier’s dry, sly farce about diplomatic life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The French Minister

results.headline: An Irish Romance With an Uncertain Future
results.summary_short: In “Stay,” a young woman living in Ireland gets pregnant and heads back home to Montreal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stay

results.headline: You Load the Uzi, Honey
results.summary_short: Based on real-life events, Raymond De Felitta’s “Rob the Mob” centers on a Queens couple who go on a holdup spree at Mafia social clubs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rob The Mob

results.headline: Is It Raging Lust, or Youthful Angst? Either Way, She’s Taking a Beating
results.summary_short: In “Nymphomaniac: Volume I,” directed by Lars von Trier, Charlotte Gainsburg plays a woman who endures suffering in the pursuit of sex.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nymphomaniac: Volume I

results.headline: Muppets, a Front for Bigger Schemes
results.summary_short: “Muppets Most Wanted,” an international caper, includes shots at Russians and the sly skewering of our European allies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Muppets Most Wanted

results.headline: Review: In ‘Divergent,’ Jolted Awake by Fear and Romance
results.summary_short: In its movie incarnation, Veronica Roth’s dystopian novel “Divergent” has high-stakes action, a gutsy teenage heroine who is an outlier, and romance between warriors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Divergent

results.display_title: From Both Sides of the Aegean
results.headline: Deportees as Pawns in a Zero-Sum Tragedy
results.summary_short: The documentary “From Both Sides of the Aegean” revisits the forced ouster of Orthodox Greeks from Turkey and Muslim Turks from Greece in the 1920s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Both Sides of the Aegean

results.headline: A Cop With a Secret
results.summary_short: Cory Monteith plays a street hustler in “McCanick,” the story of a cranky police detective (David Morse) with something to hide.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of McCanick

results.headline: The Cop and the Crook, Brothers at Odds
results.summary_short: Guillaume Canet’s remake of “Les Liens du Sang” follows two Italian-American brothers, on opposite sides of the law, in Brooklyn in 1974.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Ties

results.headline: Welcome Home. Just Avoid the Headgear
results.summary_short: “Awakened,” a thriller starring Julianne Michelle, follows a woman who has returned to her hometown to investigate her mother’s death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Awakened

results.display_title: American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs
results.headline: Tracing an Activist Through Decades
results.summary_short: In “American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs,” the director Grace Lee chronicles the life of a 98-year-old woman of Chinese descent who shares her name.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs

results.headline: In Search of a Duck, and a Way Through That Awkward Age
results.summary_short: This coming-of-age comedy, starring Ben Kingsley, is the first feature directed by Rob Meyer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Birder's Guide to Everything

results.headline: Returning, in His Own Way, to the Killing Fields
results.summary_short: In “The Missing Picture,” the director Rithy Panh uses figurines and the usual documentary devices to relay his personal story regarding Cambodia’s killing fields.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Missing Picture

results.headline: Boy Meets Girl; Boy Must Win Dad Over
results.summary_short: In the Bollywood romantic comedy “Bewakoofiyaan,” a seemingly perfect love story hits the skids when the recession leaves the man jobless.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bewakoofiyaan
